RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a Table of Contents be produced for Sets?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a Table of Contents will be generated for each Set.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-set-toc% ;; Should a Table of Contents be produced for Sets? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a Table of Contents be produced for Books?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a Table of Contents will be generated for each Book.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-book-toc% ;; Should a Table of Contents be produced for Books? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Which Lists of Titles should be produced for Books?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: This parameter should be a list (possibly empty) of the elements for which Lists of Titles should be produced for each Book.

It is meaningless to put elements that do not have titles in this list. If elements with optional titles are placed in this list, only the instances of those elements that do have titles will appear in the LOT.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define ($generate-book-lot-list$) ;; Which Lists of Titles should be produced for Books? (list (normalize "table") (normalize "figure") (normalize "example") (normalize "equation")))

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a Table of Contents be produced for Parts?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a Table of Contents will be generated for each Part. Note: %generate-part-toc-on-titlepage% controls whether the Part TOC is placed on the bottom of the part titlepage or on page(s) of its own.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-part-toc% ;; Should a Table of Contents be produced for Parts? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should the Part TOC appear on the Part title page?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the Part TOC will be placed on the Part title page. If false, the TOC will be placed on separate page(s) after the Part title page.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-part-toc-on-titlepage% ;; Should the Part TOC appear on the Part title page? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a Table of Contents be produced for References?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a Table of Contents will be generated for each Reference. Note: %generate-reference-toc-on-titlepage% controls whether the Reference TOC is placed on the bottom of the title page or on page(s) of its own.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-reference-toc% ;; Should a Table of Contents be produced for References? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should the Reference TOC appear on the Reference title page?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the Reference TOC will be placed on the Reference title page. If false, the TOC will be placed on separate page(s) after the title page.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-reference-toc-on-titlepage% ;; Should the Reference TOC appear on the Reference title page? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a Table of Contents be produced for Articles?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a Table of Contents will be generated for each Article.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-article-toc% ;; Should a Table of Contents be produced for Articles? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should the Article TOC appear on the Article title page?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the Article TOC will be placed on the Article title page. If false, the TOC will be placed on separate page(s) after the title page. If false, %generate-article-titlepage-on-separate-page% should be true.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-article-toc-on-titlepage% ;; Should the Article TOC appear on the Article title page? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a set title page be produced?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a title page will be generated for each Set.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-set-titlepage% ;; Should a set title page be produced? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a book title page be produced?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a title page will be generated for each Book.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-book-titlepage% ;; Should a book title page be produced? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a part title page be produced?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a title page will be generated for each Part.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-part-titlepage% ;; Should a part title page be produced? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should the PartIntro appear on the Part/Reference title page?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the PartIntro content will appear on the title page of Parts and References. If false, it will be placed on separate page(s) after the title page.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-partintro-on-titlepage% ;; Should the PartIntro appear on the Part/Reference title page? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should a reference title page be produced?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a title page will be generated for each Reference.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-reference-titlepage% ;; Should a reference title page be produced? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should an article title page be produced?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a title page will be generated for each Article.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-article-titlepage% ;; Should an article title page be produced? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should the article title page be on a separate page?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the title page for each Article will occur on its own page.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %generate-article-titlepage-on-separate-page% ;; Should the article title page be on a separate page? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Place elements on title page in document order?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the elements on the title page will be set in the order that they appear in the *info element. Otherwise, they will be set in the order specified in the *-titlepage-*-elements list.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %titlepage-in-info-order% ;; Place elements on title page in document order? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Author OTHERNAME appears between FIRSTNAME and SURNAME?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the OTHERNAME of an AUTHOR appears between the FIRSTNAME and SURNAME. Otherwise, OTHERNAME is suppressed.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %author-othername-in-middle% ;; Author OTHERNAME appears between FIRSTNAME and SURNAME? #t)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, each RefEntry begins on a new page.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Refentry keep indicates how the stylesheet should attempt to keep each RefEntry. Common values are #t, for the smallest possible area, page for the same page, and #f to ignore this characteristic.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, a "NAME" section title is output before the list of RefNames.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Use italic text when cross-referencing RefEntrys?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, italics are used when cross-referencing RefEntrys, either with XRef or CiteRefEntry.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %refentry-xref-italic% ;; Use italic text when cross-referencing RefEntrys? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Output manvolnum as part of RefEntry cross-reference?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the manvolnum is used when cross-referencing RefEntrys, either with XRef or CiteRefEntry.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %refentry-xref-manvolnum% ;; Output manvolnum as part of RefEntry cross-reference? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: What style of 'FuncSynopsis' should be generated?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If %funcsynopsis-style% is ansi, ANSI-style function synopses are generated for a FuncSynopsis, otherwise K&R-style function synopses are generated.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %funcsynopsis-style% ;; What style of 'FuncSynopsis' should be generated? 'ansi)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If the %funcsynopsis-style% is kr, %kr-funcsynopsis-indent% specifies the amount by which parameter definitions should be indented under the function prototype.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, elements of the FuncSynopsis will be decorated (e.g. bold or italic). The decoration is controlled by functions that can be redefined in a customization layer. See edbsynop.dsl.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: The font family used in RefName

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The name of the font family used in RefEntry RefNames.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %refentry-name-font-family% ;; The font family used in RefName %mono-font-family%)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: The font family used in titles

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The name of the font family used in titles (Arial by default).
The values used here are system dependent (you have to have the fonts you select) and backend dependent (the backend has to know how to use them).
The values here work for the RTF backend under MS Windows. YMMV.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %title-font-family% ;; The font family used in titles "Arial")

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: The font family used in body text

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The name of the font family used in body text (Times New Roman by default).
The values used here are system dependent (you have to have the fonts you select) and backend dependent (the backend has to know how to use them).
The values here work for the RTF backend under MS Windows. YMMV.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %body-font-family% ;; The font family used in body text "Times New Roman")

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: The font family used in verbatim environments

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The name of the font family used in verbatim environments (Courier New by default).
The values used here are system dependent (you have to have the fonts you select) and backend dependent (the backend has to know how to use them).
The values here work for the RTF backend under MS Windows. YMMV.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %mono-font-family% ;; The font family used in verbatim environments "Courier New")

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: The font family used in admonitions

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The name of the font family used for body text in admonitions (Arial by default).
The values used here are system dependent (you have to have the fonts you select) and backend dependent (the backend has to know how to use them).
The values here work for the RTF backend under MS Windows. YMMV.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %admon-font-family% ;; The font family used in admonitions "Arial")

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: The font family used in GUI labels

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The name of the font family used for text that represents text on a GUI (e.g., text in GUILabel, GUIMenu, etc.). (Arial by default).
The values used here are system dependent (you have to have the fonts you select) and backend dependent (the backend has to know how to use them).
The values here work for the RTF backend under MS Windows. YMMV.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %guilabel-font-family% ;; The font family used in GUI labels "Arial")

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: General measure of document text size

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: This parameter controls the general size of the text in the document. Several other values (body font size and margins) have default values that vary depending on the setting of %visual-acuity%. There are three legal values: normal, the normal, standard document size (10pt body text); tiny, a small text size (8pt body text); presbyopic, a slightly more generous size (12pt body text); and large-type, quite large (24pt body text).

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %visual-acuity% ;; General measure of document text size ;; "tiny" ;; "presbyopic" ;; "large-type" "normal")

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Internally, the stylesheet refers to font sizes in purely relative terms. This is done by defining a scaled set of fonts (sizes 1, 2, 3, etc.) based at the default text font size (e.g. 10pt). The %hsize-bump-factor% describes the ratio between scaled sizes. The default is 1.2.

Each hsize is %hsize-bump-factor% times larger than the previous hsize. For example, if the base size is 10pt, and %hsize-bump-factor% 1.2, hsize 1 is 12pt, hsize 2 is 14.4pt, hsize 3 is 17.28pt, etc.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: In environments that are usually set with a slightly smaller font size, for example block quotations, the stylesheet calculates the smaller font size by muliplying the current font size by %smaller-size-factor%.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: When text is set as a subscript or superscript, the font size of the text is multiplied by %ss-size-factor%.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: When text is set as a subscript or superscript, it is set above or below the baseline by a factor of the current font size and %ss-shift-factor%.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: When a monospace font is selected, the current font size is multiplied by the %verbatim-size-factor%. If %verbatim-size-factor% is #f, no scaling is performed (Well, thats not precisely true. In $verbatim-display$ environments, the font size is calculated with respect to the longest line in the display, if %verbatim-size-factor% is #f').

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Sets the body font size. This parameter is usually controlled by the %visual-acuity% parameter.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: When printing footnotes, the current font size is multiplied by the %footnote-size-factor%.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Specifies the title font weight (i.e., bold or medium) of formal objects (e.g., figures).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Specifies the title font weight (i.e., bold or medium) of the formal tables.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Are we using the TeX backend?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: This parameter exists so that -V tex-backend can be used on the command line to explicitly select the TeX backend.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define tex-backend ;; Are we using the TeX backend? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Are we using the MIF backend?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: This parameter exists so that -V mif-backend can be used on the command line to explicitly select the MIF backend.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define mif-backend ;; Are we using the MIF backend? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Are we using the RTF backend?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: This parameter exists so that -V rtf-backend can be used on the command line to explicitly select the RTF backend.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define rtf-backend ;; Are we using the RTF backend? #f)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: This parameter sets the default backend. Selecting an explicit backend enables features specific to that backend (if there are any). The legal values are rtf, tex, mif, and #f. Using #f implies that no special features are used.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define default-backend ;; What is the default backend? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Returns the backend that is being used to format the document

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: This parameter controls features in the stylesheet that are backend specific. The legal values are rtf, tex, mif, and #f. Using #f implies that no special features are used.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define (print-backend) ;; Returns the backend that is being used to format the document (cond (tex-backend 'tex) (mif-backend 'mif) (rtf-backend 'rtf) (else default-backend)))

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If no WIDTH attribute is specified on verbatim environments, %verbatim-default-width% is the default. Note: this width only comes into play if %verbatim-size-factor% is #f.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, lines in each Synopsis will be enumerated. See also %linenumber-mod%, %linenumber-length%, %linenumber-padchar%, and ($linenumber-space$).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, lines in each FuncSynopsisInfo will be enumerated. See also %linenumber-mod%, %linenumber-length%, %linenumber-padchar%, and ($linenumber-space$).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, lines in each LiteralLayout will be enumerated. See also %linenumber-mod%, %linenumber-length%, %linenumber-padchar%, and ($linenumber-space$).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, lines in each Address will be enumerated. See also %linenumber-mod%, %linenumber-length%, %linenumber-padchar%, and ($linenumber-space$).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, lines in each ProgramListing will be enumerated. See also %linenumber-mod%, %linenumber-length%, %linenumber-padchar%, and ($linenumber-space$).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, lines in each Screen will be enumerated. See also %linenumber-mod%, %linenumber-length%, %linenumber-padchar%, and ($linenumber-space$).

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Controls line-number frequency in enumerated environments.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Every %linenumber-mod% line will be enumerated.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %linenumber-mod% ;; Controls line-number frequency in enumerated environments. 5)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Width of line numbers in enumerated environments

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Line numbers will be padded to %linenumber-length% characters.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %linenumber-length% ;; Width of line numbers in enumerated environments 3)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Line numbers will be padded (on the left) with %linenumber-padchar%.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Returns the sosofo which separates line numbers from the text

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The sosofo returned by ($linenumber-space$) is placed between the line number and the corresponding line in enumerated environments.
Note: %linenumber-padchar%s are separated from lines that are not enumerated (because they dont match %linenumber-mod%). In other words, ($linenumber-space$)' occurs on every line.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define ($linenumber-space$) ;; Returns the sosofo which separates line numbers from the text (literal "\no-break-space;"))

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If not #f, each line in the display will be indented with the content of this variable. Usually it is set to some number of spaces, but you can indent with any string you wish.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If not #f, each line in the display will be indented with the content of this variable. Usually it is set to some number of spaces, but you can indent with any string you wish.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If not #f, each line in the display will be indented with the content of this variable. Usually it is set to some number of spaces, but you can indent with any string you wish.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If not #f, each line in the display will be indented with the content of this variable. Usually it is set to some number of spaces, but you can indent with any string you wish.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If not #f, each line in the display will be indented with the content of this variable. Usually it is set to some number of spaces, but you can indent with any string you wish.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If not #f, each line in the display will be indented with the content of this variable. Usually it is set to some number of spaces, but you can indent with any string you wish.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, fancy callout bugs will be used. Otherwise, simple ones are used. Fancy callout bugs may require the RTF backend.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If the coordinates of a callout include only a line number, the callout bug will appear in column %callout-default-col%.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, unlabeled sections will be enumerated.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, chapters will be enumerated.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Are sections in the Preface enumerated?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, unlabeled sections in the Preface will be enumerated if %section-autolabel% is true.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %label-preface-sections% ;; Are sections in the Preface enumerated? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Should numbered questions inherit the surrounding numeration?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, question numbers are prefixed with the surrounding component or section number. Has no effect unless %section-autolabel% is also true.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %qanda-inherit-numeration% ;; Should numbered questions inherit the surrounding numeration? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Generate running headers and footers on chapter-level elements?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, running headers and footers are produced on chapter-level elements.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %chap-app-running-heads% ;; Generate running headers and footers on chapter-level elements? #t)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Put chapter labels in running heads?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, running heads on Chapters and Appendixes will include an automatic label.

In other words, if a Chapter has no Label attribute, and %chap-app-running-head-autolabel% is true, running heads will include the automatic label for the Chapter. If %chap-app-running-head-autolabel% is false, only the Title (or TitleAbbrev) will appear in the running head.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %chap-app-running-head-autolabel% ;; Put chapter labels in running heads? #t)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The paper type value identifies the sort of paper in use, for example, A4 or USletter. Setting the paper type is an easy shortcut for setting the correct paper height and width.
See %page-width% and %page-height concerning what other page size are available. Some common examples are A4, USletter, A4landscape, USlandscape.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If %two-side% is true, headers and footers are alternated so that the "outer" and "inner" headers will be correctly placed in the bound document.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The writing mode is either left-to-right, or right-to-left.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Sets the number of columns on each page

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Sets the number of columns on each page

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %page-n-columns% ;; Sets the number of columns on each page 1)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Sets the number of columns on the title page

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Sets the number of columns on the title page

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %titlepage-n-columns% ;; Sets the number of columns on the title page 1)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Sets the width of the gutter between columns

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Sets the width of the gutter between columns

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %page-column-sep% ;; Sets the width of the gutter between columns 0.5in)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the columns on the final page of a multiple column layout will be balanced. Otherwise, the columns will be completely filled in the writing direction and the last column may be a different length than the preceding columns.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %left-margin% parameter specifies the width of the left margin of the page. Note that this setting is relative to the physical page, not the writing direction.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %right-margin% parameter specifies the width of the right margin of the page. Note that this setting is relative to the physical page, not the writing direction.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Identifies the width of the page (length in the writing direction). It is usually controlled by the %paper-type% parameter.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Identifies the height of the page (length perpendicular to the writing direction). It is usually controlled by the %paper-type% parameter.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specifies the width of the body column

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Identifies the width of the page on which text may occur.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %text-width% ;; Specifies the width of the body column (- %page-width% (+ %left-margin% %right-margin%)))

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specifies the left indent of epigraphs.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The indent of a epigraph. Default 55% of the text width.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %epigraph-start-indent% ;; Specifies the left indent of epigraphs. (* %text-width% 0.55))

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specified the right indent of epigraphs.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The right indent of a epigraph. Default none.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %epigraph-end-indent% ;; Specified the right indent of epigraphs. 0pt)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specifies the width of the text in the body column

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Identifies the width of the page on which text will occur, after the %body-start-indent% is removed.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %body-width% ;; Specifies the width of the text in the body column (- %text-width% %body-start-indent%))

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %top-margin% parameter specifies the height of the top margin of the page. Note that this setting is relative to the physical page, not the writing direction.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %bottom-margin% parameter specifies the height of the bottom margin of the page. Note that this setting is relative to the physical page, not the writing direction.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %header-margin% parameter specifies the heigth of the header margin of the page. Note that this setting is relative to the physical page, not the writing direction.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %footer-margin% parameter specifies the height of the footer margin of the page. Note that this setting is relative to the physical page, not the writing direction.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Restart page numbers in each component?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, page numbers are restarted at the beginning of each component-level element (Chapter, Appendix, Bibliography, etc.).

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %page-number-restart% ;; Restart page numbers in each component? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Restart page numbers in each article?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, page numbers are restarted at the beginning of each article.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %article-page-number-restart% ;; Restart page numbers in each article? #f)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, component and section titles will have the heading-level characteristic in the RTF.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, admonitions are presented in an alternate style that uses a graphic. Default graphics are provided in the distribution.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Sets the path, probably relative to the directory where the HTML files are created, to the admonition graphics. Must include trailing directory separator.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Identifies the extension for admonition graphics. This allows backends to select different images (e.g., EPS for print, PNG for PDF, etc.)
The older parameter, admon-graphic-default-extension, will be used if it is set, for backwards compatability.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %admon-graphics-extension% ;; Admonition graphic file extension (if admon-graphic-default-extension admon-graphic-default-extension ".eps"))

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Given an admonition node, returns the name of the graphic that should be used for that admonition.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing:
(define ($admon-graphic$ #!optional (nd (current-node))) ;; Admonition graphic file (cond ((equal? (gi nd) (normalize "tip")) (string-append %admon-graphics-path% (string-append "tip" %admon-graphics-extension%))) ((equal? (gi nd) (normalize "note")) (string-append %admon-graphics-path% (string-append "note" %admon-graphics-extension%)))
((equal? (gi nd) (normalize "important")) (string-append %admon-graphics-path% (string-append "important" %admon-graphics-extension%)))
((equal? (gi nd) (normalize "caution")) (string-append %admon-graphics-path% (string-append "caution" %admon-graphics-extension%))) ((equal? (gi nd) (normalize "warning")) (string-append %admon-graphics-path% (string-append "warning" %admon-graphics-extension%))) (else (error (string-append (gi nd) " is not an admonition.")))))

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Given an admonition node, returns the width of the graphic that will be used for that admonition.
All of the default graphics in the distribution are 0.3in wide.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The default quadding (start, center, justify, or end).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The quadding of division-level titles (Set, Book, and Part).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The quadding of division-level subtitles (Set, Book, and Part).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The quadding of component-level titles (Chapter, Appendix, Glossary, etc.).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The quadding of component-level subtitles (Chapter, Appendix, Glossary, etc.).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The quadding of article titles.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The quadding of article subtitles.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The quadding of section-level titles.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The quadding of section-level subtitles.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the content of CITATIONs will be checked against possible biblioentries. If the citation cannot be found, an error is issued and the citation is generated. If the citation is found, it is generated with a cross reference to the appropriate biblioentry.
A citation matches if the content of the citation element matches the ID, XREFLABEL, or leading ABBREV of a biblioentry.
This setting may have significant performance implications on large documents, hence it is false by default.
(This option can conveniently be set with -V biblio-citation-check on the Jade command line).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, bibliography entries which are not cited are suppressed. A biblioentry is cited if an XREF or LINK matches its ID, or if a CITE element matches its ID, XREFLABEL, or leading ABBREV.
A BIBLIOGRAPHY with no entries will still be output (making a whole component conditional would be _A LOT_ of work and seems unnecessary), but BIBLIDIVs with no entries will be suppressed.
This setting may have significant performance implications, hence it is false by default.
(This option can conveniently be set with -V biblio-filter-used on the Jade command line).

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, bibliography entries will be numbered. If you cross-reference bibliography entries, you should probably use biblio-number or consistently use XREFLABEL or ABBREV.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Use the titles of bibliography entries in XREFs

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, cross references to bibliography entries will use the title of the entry as the cross reference text. Otherwise, either the number (see biblio-number) or XREFLABEL/ABBREV will be used.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define biblio-xref-title ;; Use the titles of bibliography entries in XREFs #f)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The extension used to find the outline information file. When searching for outline information about a document, the extension is discarded from the system ID of the file and %olinke-outline-ext% is appended.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the URL of each ULink will appear as a footnote. Processing ULinks this way may be very, very slow. It requires walking over every descendant of every component in order to count both ulinks and footnotes.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, footnotes will be done at the bottom of the page instead of collected together as notes at the end of the section. This variable is ignored if the print backend does not support bottom-of-the-page footnotes. At present, only the TeX backend supports them.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %graphic-default-extension% will be added to the end of all fileref filenames on Graphics if they do not end in one of the %graphic-extensions%. Set this to #f to turn off this feature.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The list of extensions which may appear on a fileref on a Graphic which are indicative of graphic formats.
Filenames that end in one of these extensions will not have the %graphic-default-extension% added to them.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Load image library database for additional info about images?

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, an image library database is loaded and extra information about web graphics is retrieved from it.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define image-library ;; Load image library database for additional info about images? #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Name of the image library database

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If image-library is true, then the database is loaded from image-library-filename. It's a current limitation that only a single database can be loaded.

The image library database is stored in a separate directory because it must be parsed with the XML declaration. The only practical way to accomplish this with Jade, if you are processing a document that uses another declaration, is by having a catalog file in the directory that contains the image library that specifies the SGMLDECL. (So if it was in the same directory as your document, your document would also be parsed with the XML declaration, which may not be correct.)

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define image-library-filename ;; Name of the image library database "imagelib/imagelib.xml")

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The list of table elements in the DTD.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Width of columns in tabular simple lists

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If set to #f, the table will span the entire page width.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %simplelist-column-width% ;; Width of columns in tabular simple lists #f)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: When formatting a VariableList, this value is used as the default term length, if no TermLength is specified.
If all of the terms in a list shorter than the term length, the stylesheet may format them "side-by-side" in a table if may-format-variablelist-as-table is #t.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If %may-format-variablelist-as-table% is #t, a VariableList will be formatted as a table, if *all of* the terms are shorter than the specified TermLength.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: When a VariableList is formatted, if any of the terms in the list are too long, the whole list is formatted as a list.

If %always-format-variablelist-as-table% is #t, the VariableList will be formatted as a table, even if some terms are too long. The terms that are too long will format span above their associated description.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The leading is calculated by multiplying the current font size by the %line-spacing-factor%. For example, if the font size is 10pt and the %line-spacing-factor% is 1.1, then the text will be printed "10-on-11".

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Factor used to calculate space above a title

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The space before a title is calculated by multiplying the font size used in the title by the %head-before-factor%.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %head-before-factor% ;; Factor used to calculate space above a title 0.75)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Factor used to calculate space below a title

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The space after a title is calculated by multiplying the font size used in the title by the %head-after-factor%.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %head-after-factor% ;; Factor used to calculate space below a title 0.5)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The default indent of body text. Some elements may have more or less indentation.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %blockquote-start-indent% ;; PURP Default indent of blockquoted text ;; DESC ;; The default start (usually left) indent of blockquoted text. ;; /DESC ;; AUTHOR Ola Lundqvist ;; /REFENTRY 1em)

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %blockquote-end-indent% ;; PURP Default indent of blockquoted text ;; DESC ;; The default end (usually right) indent of blockquoted text. ;; /DESC ;; AUTHOR Ola Lundqvist ;; /REFENTRY 1em)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %para-sep% is the distance between the last line of one paragraph and the first line of the next.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %block-sep% is the vertical distance between block elements (figures, tables, etc.)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: First line start-indent for paragraphs (other than the first)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %para-indent% is the amount of extra indentation that the first line of a paragraph should receive. This parameter applies only to the second and subsequent paragraphs in a section. See %para-indent-firstpara%.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %para-indent% ;; First line start-indent for paragraphs (other than the first) 0pt)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: First line start-indent for the first paragraph

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %para-indent-firstpara% is the amount of extra indentation that the first line of the first paragraph of a section should receive. This parameter is frequently 0pt even when %para-indent% is not.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %para-indent-firstpara% ;; First line start-indent for the first paragraph 0pt)

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Block elements (tables, figures, verbatim environments, etc.) will be indented by the specified amount.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specify rules before and after an Example

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, rules will be drawn before and after each Example.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %example-rules% ;; Specify rules before and after an Example #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specify rules before and after an Figure

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, rules will be drawn before and after each Figure.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %figure-rules% ;; Specify rules before and after an Figure #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specify rules before and after an Table

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, rules will be drawn before and after each Table.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %table-rules% ;; Specify rules before and after an Table #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specify rules before and after an Equation

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, rules will be drawn before and after each Equation.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %equation-rules% ;; Specify rules before and after an Equation #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specify rules before and after an InformalExample

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, rules will be drawn before and after each InformalExample.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %informalexample-rules% ;; Specify rules before and after an InformalExample #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specify rules before and after an InformalFigure

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, rules will be drawn before and after each InformalFigure.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %informalfigure-rules% ;; Specify rules before and after an InformalFigure #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specify rules before and after an InformalTable

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, rules will be drawn before and after each InformalTable.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %informaltable-rules% ;; Specify rules before and after an InformalTable #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Specify rules before and after an InformalEquation

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, rules will be drawn before and after each InformalEquation.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %informalequation-rules% ;; Specify rules before and after an InformalEquation #f)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Width of rules around formal and informal objects

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Specifies the width of the rules drawn before and after an object. This only applies if the appropriate %*-rules% variable is #t.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %object-rule-thickness% ;; Width of rules around formal and informal objects 2pt)

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: List of objects who's titles go after the object

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: Titles of formal objects (Figures, Equations, Tables, etc.) in this list will be placed below the object instead of above it.
This is a list of element names, for example: (list (normalize "figure") (normalize "table")).

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define ($object-titles-after$) ;; List of objects who's titles go after the object '())

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, formal objects will float if floating is supported by the backend. At present, only the TeX backend supports floats.

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Default punctuation at the end of a run-in head.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The punctuation used at the end of a run-in head (e.g. on FORMALPARA).

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %default-title-end-punct% ;; Default punctuation at the end of a run-in head. ".")

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: List of punctuation chars at the end of a run-in head

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If a run-in head ends in any of these characters, the %default-title-end-punct% is not used.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %content-title-end-punct% ;; List of punctuation chars at the end of a run-in head '(#\. #\! #\? #\:))

RefNameDiv.RefPurpose: Punctuation to follow honorifics in names

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The honorific punctuation is placed after the honorific in a name.

RefSect1.Title: Source Code
RefSect1.ProgramListing: (define %honorific-punctuation% ;; Punctuation to follow honorifics in names ".")

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If SimpleSects appear inside other section-level elements, they are rendered at the appropriate section level, but if they appear in a component-level element, they are rendered at %default-simplesect-level%.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, the URL of each ULink will appear in parenthesis after the text of the link. If the text of the link and the URL are identical, the parenthetical URL is suppressed.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If true, comments will be displayed, otherwise they are suppressed. Comments here refers to the Comment element, which will be renamed Remark in DocBook V4.0, not SGML/XML comments which are unavailable.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: If #t, FIRSTTERMs will be bold, to distinguish them from simple GLOSSTERMs.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %min-leading% parameter specifies the smallest amount of leading to allow between lines. The default value, #f, has the side-effect that leading cannot change. This means that graphics that appear in a paragraph are truncated if they are taller than the current leading. By setting this parameter to some small value, we get stretchable space between lines.

RefSect1.Title: Description
RefSect1.para: The %hyphenation% parameter indicates whether or not the backend should allow automatic hyphention of text, for example in paragraphs. The default value, #f, indicates that it should not.

RefSect1.Title: Author
RefSect1.para: Norman Walsh, <ndw@nwalsh.com>
